First, LISA was used to identify the localized clustering with specific districts. For the spatial unit i, LISA is computed as [ 16]
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document} $$I_{i}=\frac{x_{i}-\overline{x}}{S^{2}}\sum\limits_{j}W_{ij}\left(x_{j}-\overline{x}\right), $$ \end{document}

where S 2 is the variance of x. A positive or negative value of I
i means spatial clustering of similar or dissimilar incidence rate, which allows to classify regions into five categories: high-high, low-low, high-low, low-high, and non-significant. The high-high and low-low areas indicated the hot and cold spots of dengue incidence, respectively. While the high-low and low-high areas were the outliers [ 16].
